questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He has also had a nonproductive cough and a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss in this period. He was treated for pneumocystis pneumonia 2 years ago. He has had skin lesions on his chest for 6 months. Five weeks ago, he went on a week-long hiking trip in Oregon. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. He says he has had trouble adhering to his medication. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows oral thrush on his palate and a white, nonscrapable plaque on the left side of the tongue. There is axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques on the chest. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4800/mm3



 CD4+ T-lymphocytes

44/mm3


Platelet count
258,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

137 mEq/L


 K+

4.9 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


One set of blood cultures grows acid-fast organisms. A PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B and itraconazole are indicated in severe pulmonary or disseminated histoplasmosis, a fungal infection that is likely to occur in patients with AIDS as a result of their impaired defense against intracellular pathogens. Histoplasmosis may also present with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, diarrhea, and acid-fastness. However, this patient has not been to regions where histoplasmosis is endemic (Mississippi and Ohio River valleys) and where he could have inhaled H. capsulatum spores from bat or bird droppings. Moreover, severely immunocompromised patients (CD4 count < 150/μL) with histoplasmosis usually present with more severe symptoms such as pancytopenia, renal failure, and shock.

Combination therapy with amphotericin B and itraconazole is also indicated in disseminated coccidioidomycosis, which may present similar to a MAC infection and is likely in a patient with HIV and low CD4 count (< 250/μL). However, the meninges are typically also affected and the fungus Coccidioides is not acid-fast. In addition, this patient has not been to regions where the fungus is endemic (e.g., certain parts of California and Arizona).
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is used in the treatment of cryptosporidiosis, which can manifest with abdominal tenderness, fever, weight loss, and diarrhea, and is more common in patients with AIDS and a CD4 count < 200/mm3. However, diarrhea is most commonly watery and severe, and respiratory findings such as dry cough and crackles on auscultation are not expected. Diagnostics would show acid-fast cysts in the stool rather than in blood cultures.

C) INCORRECT:

Rifampin and isoniazid constitute the therapeutic regimen in latent tuberculosis, which is asymptomatic. Generally (although depending on the local prevalence of TB), an induration of > 5 mm is needed to secure a diagnosis of latent TB in patients with HIV infection. The patient presenting with constitutional symptoms, fatigue, fever, and weight loss, however, would be concerning for active (and not latent) TB. However, active TB would also typically present with dyspnea, productive cough (possibly hemoptysis), and night sweats (absent in this patient.) Although bowel involvement is possible, it is a very rare complication. If the patient were to be diagnosed with active TB, the treatment regimen would be extended to rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.
Image Description:

A culture of M. tuberculosis in a petri dish on agar

After 3-4 weeks of incubation, characteristic rough, cauliflower-like, whitish-yellow colonies appear.

The complex waxy, lipid-rich cell wall of M. tuberculosis is hard to overcome for nutrients, which is why the reduplication time amounts to 12-18 hours and incubation lasts at least 3-4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole is the treatment of choice in invasive aspergillosis, which may also present with dry cough in immunocompromised patients. However, pulmonary symptoms are usually more severe (e.g., hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain). Moreover, culture results would show narrow organisms with dichotomous hyphae at a 30–45° angle after staining.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of mitral valve vegetation (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A mycelium composed of PAS positive septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at a 30–45° angle is visible.

This is the classic finding of infection with Aspergillus spp., indicating Aspergillus endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin is the first-line drug for the treatment of bacillary angiomatosis, which may also present with multiple skin lesions on the chest and constitutional symptoms such as fever, malaise, and anorexia. However, those lesions are typically red papules that bleed easily, rather than elevated violaceous plaques. This patient's skin changes are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma, which is treated with antiretroviral HIV therapy, surgical excision, and systemic interferon-alpha.

F) CORRECT:

Treatment of disseminated MAC infection consists of two or three antimycobacterial drugs. The drugs used include a macrolide (clarithromycin or azithromycin) in combination with ethambutol. Sometimes rifabutin is added as a third drug (e.g., in patients with a high mycobacterial load). Antiretroviral HIV therapy to bring the CD4 count to > 200 cells/mm3 is also recommended.
questions.hint: This patient with AIDS has a very low CD4 cell count (< 50 cells/mm3) and presents with constitutional symptoms, cough, crackles on auscultation, diarrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and acid-fast organisms in his blood culture. This makes disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection the most likely diagnosis. MAC infection typically also causes anemia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician for intermittent fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has not seen a doctor since he became uninsured 2 years ago. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm3. Blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms. A PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B and itraconazole are indicated for severe pulmonary or disseminated histoplasmosis and disseminated coccidioidomycosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis is caused by an acid-fast organism and manifests with fever and hepatosplenomegaly, which are seen in this patient. However, it is an unlikely cause of this patient's infection because he has not traveled to regions where histoplasmosis is endemic (the Mississippi and Ohio River Valley) and has not been exposed to bat or bird droppings (the primary vectors of Histoplasma capsulatum spores). Coccidioides, on the other hand, is not an acid-fast organism, and the patient has not traveled to regions where it is endemic (e.g., California and Arizona).
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is used in the treatment of cryptosporidiosis, which manifests with the constitutional symptoms and abdominal tenderness that are seen in this patient. This patient's immunosuppression (e.g., CD4 count ≤ 200/μL) is a risk factor for cryptosporidiosis. However, this disease does not manifest with respiratory findings (e.g., dry cough), and blood cultures would not grow acid-fast organisms. Instead, acid-fast cysts would be seen in stool cultures.
Image Description:

Fecal sample of a patient with cryptosporidiosis

Several round oocysts (red) that contain a large number of sporozoites. Oocysts are highly resistant to environmental factors and disinfectants (also to chlorine, e.g., in drinking water). They are the infective form of the parasite Cryptosporidium parvum.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin is the first-line treatment for bacillary angiomatosis, which does manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, and anorexia). Affected patients also develop multiple red papules that bleed easily on the chest, extremities, and/or face. However, this patient has no skin lesions suggestive of this condition.

D) CORRECT:

The combination of azithromycin (or clarithromycin) and ethambutol is used to treat disseminated MAC infection, which manifests with constitutional symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. In some cases, rifabutin is included as a third drug, particularly for patients with a high mycobacterial load. Patients should also receive antiretroviral HIV therapy to improve the CD4 count.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin and isoniazid are used to treat latent tuberculosis, which is by definition asymptomatic. The constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, fever, and weight loss) seen in this patient are manifestations of active TB (not latent TB). Although this patient's skin test was negative (induration < 5 mm), a CD4 count < 200 may lead to a false-negative result and should be repeated once the CD4 count rises above this threshold. Active TB typically manifests with symptoms such as dyspnea, productive cough (possibly hemoptysis), and night sweats, none of which are seen in this patient. The treatment regimen for active TB includes rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

Since TB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and all mycobacteria are acid-fast, culture results are not useful in determining which species is causing the infection in this case.
Image Description:

A culture of M. tuberculosis in a petri dish on agar

After 3-4 weeks of incubation, characteristic rough, cauliflower-like, whitish-yellow colonies appear.

The complex waxy, lipid-rich cell wall of M. tuberculosis is hard to overcome for nutrients, which is why the reduplication time amounts to 12-18 hours and incubation lasts at least 3-4 weeks.
questions.hint: This patient with AIDS has a very low CD4 cell count (< 50 cells/mm3) and has constitutional symptoms, cough, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and acid-fast organisms in his blood culture, making disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old previously healthy woman reports a 6-month history of cough and low-grade fevers, a 7-kg weight loss, and increasing shortness of breath. Her cough produces thick white sputum. She has never used tobacco.
On examination, she appears thin but is in no distress. Her vital signs are normal. On pulmonary auscultation, there are crackles in the right middle and lower lobes. A chest radiograph reveals bronchiectasis and nodular opacities in the right middle lobe.
Which one of the following findings is most likely to be seen on sputum culture from this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Histoplamosis is caused by a budding yeast, but bronchiectasis is not a typical risk factor for histoplasmosis.

B) CORRECT:

Mycobacterium avium complex is ubiquitous in the environment and is the most frequent cause of pulmonary infection due to nontuberculous mycobacteria in the United States. Patients with isolated pulmonary M.avium complex are typically immunocompetent adults, most commonly with underlying lung disease, or postmenopausal women who present with a chronic cough and have nodular opacities with bronchiectasis in the right middle lobe on chest imaging (Lady Windermere syndrome). Sputum cultures show acid-fast bacilli.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of chronic cough, fever, and weight loss in an older woman who is found to have bronchiectasis and nodular opacities on chest imaging is Mycobacterium avium complex infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Small, pleomorphic gram-positive rods include organisms such as Rhodococcus, Listeria, Corynebacterium, and Propionibacterium. Although Rhodococcus can cause respiratory infection, immunocompromised hosts are particularly prone to this type of pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive diplococci would be seen with Streptococcus pneumoniae infection, which manifests with acute pulmonary symptoms and lobar consolidation.

E) INCORRECT:

Candida is a yeast that may form pseudohyphae, but this organism is an uncommon cause of respiratory infection.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with AIDS is hospitalized with a 3-week history of fatigue, night sweats, fevers (up to 38.4°C), and a 5- to 10-kg weight loss. Three months ago, her CD4 count was 35 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600), her CD4 percentage was 4%, and her viral load was 121,000 copies/mL. She has never taken antiretroviral therapy.
Blood cultures for acid-fast bacilli grow Mycobacterium avium complex. Susceptibility results are not yet available.
Which one of the following antimycobacterial regimens should be started in this patient?

choices.text: Clarithromycin and ethambutol, with or without rifabutin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection can occur in patients with advanced HIV-related immunosuppression; in most cases, their CD4 count is <50 cells per mm3, and they are not taking antiretroviral therapy or have only recently started it. Combination therapy directed at the organism is indicated, along with HIV treatment.

The backbone of treatment for MAC infection is a macrolide antibiotic (usually clarithromycin because there is more evidence to support its efficacy than azithromycin). The macrolide antibiotic is combined with ethambutol as a second antimycobacterial drug. Ethambutol helps prevent the development of drug resistance to the macrolide. Some experts also add a rifamycin drug (rifampin or rifabutin), which may improve survival and be associated with lower rates of drug resistance, but close attention needs to be paid to potential interactions with other medications such as HIV protease inhibitors.

Key learning point: In a patient with AIDS who develops disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex disease, the recommended antimycobacterial regimen include clarithromycin and ethambutol, with or without rifabutin.

B) INCORRECT:

Clofazimine should not be included as part of the antimycobacterial regimen; in a randomized trial, a group that received combination therapy including clofazimine had a higher mortality rate than a group that received combination therapy without clofazimine. In addition, ethambutol, rather than rifampin, should be the preferred second agent when treating Mycobacterium avium complex infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used to treat pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), not Mycobacterium avium complex. This patient should receive trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for PCP prophylaxis but not as treatment for Mycobacterium avium complex.

D) INCORRECT:

The backbone of treatment for Mycobacterium avium complex infection is a macrolide antibiotic (usually clarithromycin because there is more evidence to support its efficacy than azithromycin).

E) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid is a key drug in treating Mycobacterium tuberculosis but is not active against Mycobacterium avium complex.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with AIDS and a CD4 count of 35 cells/μL presents with fever, night sweats, and 6.8-kg (15-pound) weight loss over 4 weeks. Examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL, WBC count 2,800/μL, alkaline phosphatase 380 U/L, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase 210 U/L. Blood cultures are pending. What is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This four-drug regimen is appropriate for primary tuberculosis. However, the constellation of hepatosplenomegaly, leukopenia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase with gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase more strongly suggests Mycobacterium avium complex infection than tuberculosis in this clinical context.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of constitutional symptoms with hepatosplenomegaly, leukopenia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase with gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase in a patient with a CD4 count < 50 cells/μL is highly suggestive of disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection. Initial treatment requires at least two antimicrobial drugs, with clarithromycin and ethambutol being the preferred first-line regimen. Because this patient's CD4 count is < 50 cells/μL, he is at increased risk of death, and a third antimicrobial, such as rifabutin, is often recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is used for cytomegalovirus infections, which typically have organ-specific manifestations such as retinitis, colitis, or pneumonitis rather than the systemic findings and specific laboratory findings seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal agent that is not effective against mycobacterial infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which typically manifests with respiratory symptoms and does not cause hepatosplenomegaly or the specific laboratory findings seen here.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a new diagnosis of HIV and CD4 count of 67 cells/μL presents with 3 weeks of fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show anemia, leukopenia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. Blood cultures are positive for acid-fast bacilli, and molecular testing confirms Mycobacterium avium complex. The patient has no known drug allergies and is not currently on antiretroviral therapy. What is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with clarithromycin is inappropriate for Mycobacterium avium complex infection as it leads to rapid development of antimicrobial resistance. Treatment requires at least two antimicrobial drugs to prevent resistance and ensure therapeutic efficacy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The initial regimen for Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection requires at least two antimicrobial drugs, with the preferred combination being clarithromycin (first-line macrolide) and ethambutol. This two-drug combination provides effective coverage against MAC while minimizing the development of resistance. Additional drugs are reserved for patients at high risk with specific indications.

C) INCORRECT:

This regimen contains appropriate drugs for the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex infection, but it is unnecessarily complex for initial therapy. Rifabutin and moxifloxacin are optional third and fourth drugs reserved for patients with high mortality risk, drug resistance, or high mycobacterial load; they are not part of standard initial therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The standard regimen for the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex infection is clarithromycin and ethambutol. Levofloxacin is an optional third drug considered for patients with high mortality risk, drug resistance, or inadequate response to standard therapy, not for routine initial treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination represents a regimen for tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Mycobacterium avium complex has different antimicrobial susceptibilities and requires macrolide-based therapy rather than the isoniazid/rifampin combination used for tuberculosis.
